text.p: SME - The government coalition is preparing further personnel changes in the state administration and special screening committees are being set up.

- Augustin Marian Huska, deputy chairman of the Movement for a Democratic Slovakia says in an interview that the decision on whether Slovakia will be invited to join NATO will depend on an agreement between Russia and the U.S.
- New postal tarrifs with prices up to 20 percent higher are in force as of April 1 in Slovakia.

SLOVENSKA REPUBLIKA - The senate of the International Court in The Hague arrive in Slovakia on Tuesday for an on-site inspection of the Gabcikovo dam, the centre of a judicial argument between Slovakia and Hungary. This is the first time the court has ever left The Hague.
- A group of skinheads in Prievidza on Friday attacked and seriously injured a 45 -year-old gypsy. The man is still in a serious condition.

HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The Slovak bank sector fulfilled its minimum reserve committments to over 100 percent at the second March deadline, during which it was short, leading to a rapid rise in short-term interbank rates which culminated in a span of 30 to 35 percent on Thursday.
- Wages in Slovakia are growing faster than labour productivity.
NARODNA OBRODA - The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the draft law on state support for ailing companies could lead to undermining financial discipline in the entire economy.
- Alojz Englis, former leader of the Slovak Confederation of Trade Unions said he had resigned as deputy chairman of the confederation due to disputes within the body.

- President Michal Kovac has recommended that the population vote "yes" in the two referenda to be held at the end of May - on Slovakia's willingness to join NATO and on the direct election of the president.
PRAVDA - German police have detained a 41-year-old Slovak suspected to have defrauded the National Bank of Slovakia of six million DM.
- Slovak Prime MInister Vladimir Meciar will pay an official three-day visit to Turkey from April 2.

PRACA - The state privatisation agency, the National Property Fund interprets the law as it pleases, ignores rulings of the constitutional court and has no external or internal controls of its activities, says opposition deputy Brigita Schmoegnerova in an interview.
